docs.lead_paragraph: THE Republican governors were the farm team for their party in the 1990's. Assisted by a national boom that produced a gusher of state revenues, these executives made their names by cutting taxes and pushing for innovative solutions on welfare, education, health care and the environment. At the same time, they were staunch allies to Republicans in Washington, cooperating in efforts to reduce the federal role in designing and carrying out social policy.

headline.main: The Nation; Holding Republican Governors' Feats to the Fire

docs.abstract: Daniel Gross article on Republican governors, many of them elected in time to spend money on innovative social programs and cut taxes during economic boom, who must now cut their programs or raise taxes they cut; Republicans are proving that they, like their Democratic counterparts, will resort to fiscal gimmicks to close budget gaps; photo (M)
docs.snippet: THE Republican governors were the farm team for their party in the 1990's. Assisted by a national boom that produced a gusher of state revenues, these executives made their names by cutting taxes and pushing for innovative solutions on welfare,...

docs.lead_paragraph: The final chapter in the health insurance scandal that cost Nassau County taxpayers tens of millions of dollars is headed for Federal District Court next week as three defendants in the case go on trial. Two more defendants are expected to plead guilty on Monday and agree to testify for the prosecution, according to Joseph Conway, an assistant United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York.

headline.main: 2 More Expected to Plead Guilty In a Nassau Insurance Scandal

docs.abstract: Trial is scheduled to begin for Albert E Isernio, Michael Agoglia and Robert Friedman, who were involved with scheme to defraud Nassau County, NY, of millions of dollars by giving preference to new health insurance company for county workers that ended up costing county up to $70 million and netted $12.5 million in illicit fees; William Michael Blake and brother John R Blake plead guilty to variety of charges and face sentences of up to 35 years (M)
docs.snippet: The final chapter in the health insurance scandal that cost Nassau County taxpayers tens of millions of dollars is headed for Federal District Court next week as three defendants in the case go on trial.    Two more defendants are expected to plead...

docs.lead_paragraph: AT the University of Connecticut campus in Storrs, construction workers are already as common a sight as students as the the hard hats scramble to finish a modernization program in 2005. Now more projects are on the horizon. A new building program designed to put the finishing touches to what one university official called ''a state of the art campus'' will keep the payloaders and bulldozers around through at least 2015. The present makeover project, called UConn 2000 and started in 1995, has already changed the face of the campus. Two parking garages with a combined 2,500 spaces, a $56 million chemistry building, a $26.6 million business school and a $42.9 million biological sciences building have opened. An information technology center costing $34.1 million is nearly finished and work will start soon on a $40 million pharmacy building.

headline.main: In the Region/Connecticut; UConn Speeds Toward 'a State of the Art Campus'

docs.lead_paragraph: In the days before bumper stickers told us to question authority, authority was one of the engines that kept society moving along. Teachers, police officers and clergy members were the people whose sudden entrance into a room made us stamp out cigarettes and stand up straight. We respected them, and with that respect came a healthy twinge of fear coupled with a desire to please. But then some teachers met chaotic classrooms with lower academic standards, some cops reached too quickly for a gun and some members of the clergy did things that defied our imagination. The people in those professions who deserved to have authority lost it in the tides of scandal. Over time we forgot that the word ''authority'' ever had a good definition. After all, American political authority had slipped with the witch hunts of McCarthy, stumbled with L.B.J. in Vietnam and fell with a resounding permanence in Watergate. Our leaders had looked us in the eye on national television, and they had lied. Of all the professions, only medicine seems to have managed to hold on to the edges of the old-fashioned order. People will wait eight hours in an emergency room and still manage to be respectful when the doctor arrives in the cubical. We understand that he or she was working, probably saving a life and not throwing darts in the lounge. The sight of a white coat moves us in a way that a blue uniform or a clerical collar does not. We still believe, no matter what the wait or cost or tortured insurance forms, that this person is here to help us. What he or she knows we could not possibly figure out on our own.
docs.abstract: Ann Patchett article says that in a time when politicians, clergy and teachers have all lost some of their aura as authority figures, doctors have maintained their moral authority and could perhaps can help cure what ails our political system; says that Sen Bill Frist, doctor, makes good replacement for Trent Lott as Senate majority leader and that an enlightening presidential contest might be between Frist and Gov Howard Dean, Democratic presidential aspirant who is also a doctor; illus (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIMES, in the crush of news, seemingly minor things that later prove significant are overlooked. That may have been the case last fall when Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana said he had changed his mind and was now calling for universal health care coverage because the American system of medical care ''is collapsing around us.''

headline.main: Why a Centrist (No Fooling) Wants Universal Insurance

docs.abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on Sen John B Breaux's unherald shift to support for universal health care coverage; holds key shift could lead to legislation changing face of health care in United States; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks ended the old year on a slight upward trend and began 2003 like a firecracker. Thursday, the opening trading day of the year, was the best first day since 1988. Unexpected good news about the health of the nation's manufacturers was the major catalyst for the Thursday surge. A settlement in a contentious, Enron-related lawsuit involving J. P. Morgan Chase and a group of insurance companies also helped.

headline.main: DataBank; If Only a Week Could Last a Whole Year

docs.abstract: Summary of week's markets' trading; graphs; tables (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Their hospital began to shrink about nine weeks ago. First, the hospice didn't reopen after renovations. Then came a directive: Send all the patients to the campus in Downtown Brooklyn. The door to the intensive care unit was padlocked shut.

headline.main: A Small Hospital Closes, and Its Friends Mourn

docs.abstract: Local residents decry upcoming closing of Brooklyn Hospital Center's Caledonian campus on Parkside Drive in Flatbush, Brooklyn; Caledonian campus would be replaced with diagnostic and treatment center; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Their hospital began to shrink about nine weeks ago.      First, the hospice didn't reopen after renovations. Then came a directive: Send all the patients to the campus in Downtown Brooklyn. The door to the intensive care unit was padlocked shut.

docs.lead_paragraph: When George W. Bush took the oath of office two years ago, many people doubted that he would ever be able to govern effectively. During the campaign, an unprophetic pundit observed on TV, ''One thing George Bush is going to have trouble asserting when he gets to office is that he's got a mandate for government.'' That unprophetic pundit was me. In the 24 months since Inauguration Day, Mr. Bush has made his own mandate. Today, Mr. Bush is more than a strong president: he dominates his own party in a way that few modern presidents ever have.
docs.abstract: David Frum Op-Ed article holds Pres Bush has made own mandate, dominating his party in way few modern presidents have; notes he has been accepted by all important Republican factions without any public dissent; holds he has been more cautious than Pres Ronald Reagan on economy, far bolder on social issues and has unexpectedly led Republicans into activisim on foreign policy; drawing (M)o

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Bush to Propose Sweeping Changes in Medicare Plan'' (front page, Jan. 3): While health care is a complicated issue, all I can think of is the rising costs over the years of ''competitive'' health insurance (and H.M.O.) coverage. Thus, I'm assuming that to open Medicare up to competition will not at all keep costs down.
docs.abstract: Nancy Gerson letter on Jan 3 article warns against Pres Bush's plan to open up Medicare to competition
